prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the post (the author) is in the wrong. The situation is about their husband setting up his home office in their bedroom, leading to conflicts with responsibilities and work-life balance.

First, I need to break down the key points. The husband works from home part-time and chose the bedroom as his office. The author suggested the basement, which is quieter, but he prefers the bedroom for the view. His job involves a lot of conference calls, so the author has to prevent the kids from disturbing him. This restriction limits her ability to use the top floor, take a shower, do chores, etc. She works from home too and does most of the housework and childcare. She told him that if he's in the basement, they won't disturb him, but she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom.

The core issue here is about shared space and priorities. The husband values the view and convenience of the bedroom, while the author needs her space for work and chores. The husband's choice to work in the bedroom creates constraints for the author's daily life. The author's argument is that she's not the problem; it's his choice to be in a location that's harder to manage.

From a fairness perspective, if both are working from home and sharing responsibilities, their workspaces should ideally minimize disruption to each other. The basement option was presented as a solution that would allow both to work without interference. The husband's refusal to take the basement might be the root of the problem here. The author is not being inconsiderate; she's trying to balance work and home duties. The husband's setup is causing her to handle more stress and limitations. So, the author isn't in the wrong for not keeping him undisturbed if he's in a space that's not optimal for shared living. The answer would be B (No), because the husband's decision to set up in the bedroom creates the conflict, not the author's actions in managing her responsibilities.
